seo.title: Roof Area Calculator - Estimate Roof Surface Area for Materials
seo.description: Easily calculate the total surface area of your roof, including slopes and overhangs. Perfect for estimating shingles, tiles, or roofing felt for simple gable roofs.

inputs.label: Roof Pitch Run (Always 12 inches)
inputs.description: Standard roof pitch run is 12 inches.

outputs.label: Total Roof Surface Area
outputs.description: The total sloped surface area of your roof, including overhangs, for material estimation.

outputs.label: Roof Pitch in Degrees
outputs.description: The angle of the roof slope relative to the horizontal plane.

outputs.label: Roof Slope Factor
outputs.description: The multiplier used to convert horizontal area to sloped area. A higher factor indicates a steeper pitch.

faq.question: What type of roofs does this calculator work for?
faq.answer: This calculator is primarily designed for simple gable roofs (two sloped sides with a ridge). For more complex roof structures like hips, mansards, or multiple gables, you may need to break down the roof into simpler sections and calculate each separately.

faq.question: Does this calculation include overhangs?
faq.answer: Yes, this calculator includes both eave and gable overhangs in the total surface area calculation, providing a more accurate estimate for material needs.

faq.question: How do I measure roof pitch?
faq.answer: Roof pitch is expressed as a ratio, typically 'rise over run' (e.g., 6/12). To measure it, place a level horizontally against a rafter or exposed roof decking. Measure 12 inches horizontally along the level, then measure vertically from the 12-inch mark on the level down to the rafter/decking. This vertical measurement is your 'rise'.

faq.question: Why is roof area important?
faq.answer: Knowing your roof's total surface area is crucial for accurately estimating the amount of materials needed (like shingles, tiles, underlayment), planning for solar panel installations, or getting quotes for roof repairs or replacement. It also helps in calculating insulation requirements and storm drainage.
